title:
Tracking the coal to clean transition:
Coal phaseout stats from the Global Coal Plant Tracker
footer: All data comes from GEM's [Global Coal Plant Tracker](https://globalenergymonitor.org/projects/global-coal-plant-tracker/), last updated in July 2024. Total operating capacity (GW) includes mothballed plants.

dropdown.overall_summary: According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, advanced economies should phase out all unabated coal power by 2030 and the rest of the world by 2040. As of January 2025, there are plans to retire 14% (301.4 GW) of the world's 2158.2 GW operating coal fleet by 2040. The world as a whole has not yet pledged to phase out coal power on a specific timeline, although several individual countries and regions have.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, G7 nations as advanced economies should phase out all unabated coal power by 2030. As of January 2025, G7 plans to retire 35% (105.4 GW) of its 300.0 GW operating coal fleet by 2030. The G7 have committed to phasing out coal power by 2035.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, advanced economies should phase out all unabated coal power by 2030 and the rest of the world by 2040. Several G20 countries are considered advanced economies. As of January 2025, G20 plans to retire 13% (264.8 GW) of its 1981.6 GW operating coal fleet by 2040. The G20 as a group has not committed to phasing out coal power, although some individual G20 countries have.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, EU27 should phase out all unabated coal power by 2030. As of January 2025, EU27 plans to retire 46% (46.5 GW) of its 102.2 GW operating coal fleet by 2030. EU27 has not pledged to phase out coal power.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, advanced economies should phase out all unabated coal power by 2030 and the rest of the world by 2040. Most countries within the OECD are considered advanced economies. As of January 2025, OECD plans to retire 32% (145.4 GW) of its 448.1 GW operating coal fleet by 2030. The OECD as a group has not committed to phasing out coal power, although some individual OECD countries have.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, BRICS countries should phase out all unabated coal power by 2040. As of January 2025, BRICS plans to retire 2.8% (41.9 GW) of its 1479.0 GW operating coal fleet by 2040. BRICS countries have not made a pledge to phase out coal power.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, Albania should phase out all unabated coal power by 2040. Albania has no operating coal power. Albania has not pledged to phase out coal power.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, Argentina should phase out all unabated coal power by 2040. As of January 2025, Argentina plans to retire 76% (0.4 GW) of its 0.5 GW operating coal fleet by 2040. Argentina has not pledged to phase out coal power.

According to the 1.5C pathway in IEA's Net Zero scenario, Austria should phase out all unabated coal power by 2030. Austria has no operating coal power. Austria has pledged to phase out coal by 2020.
